div.bibl: Illinois Staats-Zeitung, Aug. 5, 1893. THOMAS LEAVES! BUREAU OF MUSIC LOSES ITS LEADER.

body.p: p. 5 - The conjectures which have circulated so freely for some time, have become a reality. Theodore Thomas, the director of the Music Bureau is leaving. He sent in his resignation to Manager Davis yesterday afternoon.

In his letter, Mr. Thomas mentions the exposition's sad financial plight and further declares that economy is a necessity. He says that the engagements of foreign and American artists were dropped from the program and that his original plans had been altered so much as to become non-existent. For the remainder of the season, music must be considered as a pleasure instead of an art; the scarcity of money requires it.

He offered to help the directorate in an advisory capacity, gratuitously.
The directors regret losing such a capable man; but financially his departure is a gain. His monthly salary was $1,666. His administrative expenses, including the cost of the hall, amounted to $700,000, and if he had remained another three months, there would have been an additional expense of $400,000. These expenditures, obviously, are too great, as the income up to the present time has only been $100,000.
